Fig. 1 Position of the cluster employed in the present calculations within the ZSM-5 structure observed (a) along the linear channels and (b) along the sinusoidal channels. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Si46Al2O116H40Cu2 cluster employed for the calculations presented in the forthcoming sections. Within the two-layer ONIOM approach, the region treated at higher computational level is represented as ball-and-sticks, that treated at lower level as only sticks. (b) The high-level part of the cluster, Si8Al2O31H22Cu2, with the corresponding crystallographic atom numbering [46]. Notice that O atoms follow an independent numbering with respect to Si and Al atoms. Fig 2 Fig. 3 First mechanism identified for the spin-allowed decomposition of NO. The relative energy of each structure was calculated with respect to that of the free catalyst (ZCu2) plus two gas-phase NO molecules. Relative energies (kcal mol−1) are reported in brackets from left to right as electronic energy + zero-point energy (E 0+ZPE) and also with Gibbs free energy contributions at 298.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 298.15) and at 773.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 773.15). 2S+1 is the spin multiplicity of each structure. Selected interatomic distances (black), Mulliken charges (red) and spin densities (blue/italics) are also reported. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Second mechanism identified for the spin-allowed decomposition of NO. From the free catalyst, ZCu2 + 2NO (zero of the energy scale) to the 06 structure, the mechanism is the same as in Fig. 3. Relative energies (kcal mol−1) are reported in brackets from left to right as electronic energy + zero-point energy (E 0+ZPE) and also with Gibbs free energy contributions at 298.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 298.15) and at 773.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 773.15). 2S+1 is the spin multiplicity of each structure. Selected interatomic distances (black), Mulliken charges (red) and spin densities (blue/italics) are also reported. Fig 4 S Fig. 5 Mechanism identified for the spin-forbidden decomposition of NO. Up to the formation of the 06 structure the mechanism is the same as in Figs. 3-4. The relative energy (kcal mol−1) of each structure was calculated with respect to that of two active sites (ZCu2) plus three gas-phase NO molecules. The active species in each step are indicated in red. Relative energies (kcal mol−1) are reported in brackets from left to right as electronic energy + zero-point energy (E 0+ZPE) and also with Gibbs free energy contributions at 298.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 298.15) and at 773.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 773.15). 2S+1 is the spin multiplicity of each structure. Selected interatomic distances (black), Mulliken charges (red) and spin densities (blue/italics) are also reported. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Plot showing the interaction energy (kcal mol−1) between N2O and the free active site (ZCu2) as a function of the r(O−N) interatomic distance of N2O. White circles (○) correspond to singlet state (2S+1 = 1) energies, grey-filled circles (◍) correspond to triplet state (2S+1 = 3) energies. Black squares (■) represent some of the structures shown in Fig. 5. The zero of the energy scale was taken as the sum of the electronic energy of ZCu2 plus that of N2O. The position of ZCu2O + gas-phase N2 along the r(O−N) axis was obtained by extrapolating the triplet state curve to the corresponding energy value. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Additional structures optimised for the Cu-pair active site. Energies (kcal mol−1, in brackets) are calculated as follows: for structures 19‒21 as relative energies with respect to ZCu2+2NO, for 22‒24 with respect to 2ZCu2+3NO, for 24‒30 as interaction energies between the catalyst and the adsorbed molecules. For 24 both relative and interaction energies are given. Energies are calculated at 0.0, 273.15 and 773.15 K, as in Figs. 3‒5. 2S+1 is the spin multiplicity of each structure. Selected interatomic distances (black), Mulliken charges (red) and spin densities (blue/italics) are also reported. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Additional structures optimised for the single-Cu active site. Energies (kcal mol−1, in brackets) are calculated as interaction energies between the catalyst and the adsorbed molecules. Energies are calculated at 0.0, 273.15 and 773.15 K, as in Figs. 3-5. 2S+1 is the spin multiplicity of each structure. Selected interatomic distances (black), Mulliken charges (red) and spin densities (blue/italics) are also reported. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Reaction paths identified for the NO decomposition and employed in the kinetic analysis: (a) reaction paths based on the spin-allowed N2O decomposition, as shown in Fig. 3 (black-red lines) and in Fig. 4 (black line); (b) reaction path based on the spin-forbidden N2O decomposition, as shown in Fig. 5. In all cases are shown the energetics obtained at 0 K, based on the electronic energy + zero-point vibrational energy (E 0+ZPE) and also with Gibbs free energy corrections at 298.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 298.15) and at 773.15 K (E 0+ZPE+ΔG 773.15). Fig 9 Table 1 Turnover Frequency (TOF/s − 1) calculated at 773.15 K according to the Kozuch e Shaik model [42–45] for the NO decomposition occurring through the spin-allowed reaction path as in Figs. 3, 4, 9(a) and through the spin-forbidden reaction path, as in Figs. 5, 9(b). For each reaction path, the TOF-Determining Intermediate (TDI) and to the TOF-Determining Transition State (TDTS) calculated at 773.15 K are shown. In the last row, the Energetic Span (kcal mol−1) calculated at 0.0, 298.15 e 773.15 K is also reported. The decomposition of NO catalysed by Cu+ pairs coordinated at the Al-substituted T3 sites of the 10-membered rings of Cu-ZSM-5 was studied by means of DFT/ONIOM calculations. Three mechanisms for NO decomposition were defined on the active site, all based on the formation and further decomposition of an hyponitrite anion, which gives the N2O molecule and a [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ bridge, where both copper ions are oxidized. N2O can react with the oxidized active site according to two different spin-allowed mechanisms which give immediately the products, N2 + O2. Otherwise, N2O reacts with a new reduced site according to a spin-forbidden mechanism which gives N2 and a second [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ bridge. When the latter mechanism occurs, reduced sites are restored by further reaction of [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ with NO and desorption of NO2, which is finally decomposed on a second [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ site, giving O2 + NO. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) calculated by means of the Energetic Span model showed that one of the spin-allowed mechanisms should be relatively fast, whereas the spin-forbidden one is expected to be extremely slow. Computational results were discussed with reference to experimental data available in the literature. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu-ZSM-5 NO decomposition N2O decomposition DFT Energetic Span Model Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction It is well established since 1986 [1,2] that even at relatively low temperature (673–773 K) Cu-ZSM-5 is a powerful catalyst for the NO decomposition reaction (2NO → N2 + O2) otherwise slow if not catalysed or in the presence of many other catalysts [3–8]. Despite the massive amount of studies on this topic, after many years from the first publications the nature of the active site of Cu-ZSM-5 and the related reaction mechanism are not yet fully clarified. Some authors initially suggested that the active site contains a single Cu+ ion [8–11] but further considerations based on the dependence of the reaction turnover frequency (TOF) on the aluminium and copper content of the catalyst led other authors [12–18] to hypothesize that the active site may be formed by Cu+ pairs. In conjunction with experiments, quantum mechanical calculations were extensively employed to investigate both the structural features and the reactivity of Cu-ZSM-5. The ability of several potential catalytic sites to host Cu+ [19], Cu2+ [20] or pairs of Cu+ ions [21] was studied by suitable quantum chemical codes [22,23]. The interaction between the possible active sites and probe molecules such as NO or CO was investigated by DFT methods which employed both localized orbitals and/or a plane-wave approach [24–27]. DFT calculations also showed that the single-step concerted 2NO → N2 + O2 reaction is forbidden by orbital symmetry both in the gas-phase and in the presence of a catalyst [28], so that multi-step mechanisms are required to perform the NO decomposition [28–38]. It is known that the first step of the process is the reaction of two NO molecules on the active site (ZCu or ZCu2, where Z=zeolite) which leads to the formation of N2O as a reaction intermediate and leaves an O atom on the active site [28–30]. After this, N2O may immediately react with the oxidized form of a catalyst, namely ZCuO or ZCu2O, to give N2 + O2 in one step, restoring the reduced form of the catalyst at the same time [29,30]. This mechanism is said to be spin-allowed because reactants, intermediates and products are all stable in the triplet spin state. Otherwise, N2O may react again with the reduced form of the catalyst, ZCu or ZCu2, to give N2 and a second oxidized active site, ZCuO or ZCu2O [31,32]. In this case, the action of moving the remaining O atom from an active site to another one to form O2 may be performed by NO itself, through the formation and the further decomposition of NO2 [33–35]. At difference from the former spin-allowed mechanism, the latter one is characterized by spin-forbidden elementary steps which are anyway made feasible by the catalytic action of Cu-ZSM-5. In this framework, a study based on spectroscopic methods and DFT calculations [38] suggested that the direct spin-forbidden N2O decomposition is catalysed by an active site based on a pair of Cu+ ions placed at about 4–4.5 Å from each other. These are both coordinated by two oxygens of the corresponding Al T-sites, which are separated by two Si T-sites. When N2O decomposes, this allows the formation of a stable [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+intermediate, which plays a key role in lowering the activation energy of the spin-forbidden reaction. The same site of Cu-ZSM-5 was also considered to be active in the oxidation of methane to methanol [39,40] and a similar one was found to be involved in the same reaction catalysed by Cu-MOR [41]. The catalytic site of Cu-ZSM-5, in particular, was assumed to be located along the 10-membered rings in the region were the linear and the sinusoidal channels of ZSM-5 intersect. In spite of such indications, the article [38] did not allow a certain identification of the catalytic site because the cluster models adopted for calculations were provided without the crystallographic numbering of the zeolite T-sites, and also because the geometries made available as supplementary material could not unambiguously be referred to any specific crystal portion. Moreover, the above investigation [38] was focused on a single step of the possible reaction mechanism, i.e. the ZCu2 + N2O → ZCu2‒ON2 → ZCu2O + N2 spin-forbidden reaction, and did not explain how the reduced catalyst, ZCu2, regenerates from ZCu2O in order to restart the catalytic cycle. In this context, the present study is aimed at a more certain identification of the active site within the zeolite structure and, at the same time, at defining the complete reaction mechanism for NO decomposition on the chosen site, taking into consideration that N2O is a well established intermediate for the latter process. Detailed energetics of both minima and transition states along the possible reaction paths are shown and discussed. The related energetic profiles are employed for a quantitative calculation of the corresponding turnover frequencies (TOFs) according to the Energetic Span Model, developed by Kozuch and Shaik [42–45]. Computational methods The catalytic site investigated in the present study lays along a 10-membered ring located at the intersection between the linear and the sinusoidal channels of ZSM-5. It was simulated by means of the Si46Al2O116H40Cu2 cluster ( Fig. 1 ) extracted from the crystallographic structure of orthorhombic H-ZSM-5 [46]. The Al/Si substitution was performed at the T3 crystallographic sites, with the concomitant addition of two Cu+ ions. The total cluster charge was set to zero in the calculations, so that a formal Cu+ ion corresponds to each Al3+ ion of the zeolite framework. Each terminal Si atom at the cluster boundaries ( Fig. 1 ) was replaced by a H atom laying along the direction of the truncated O‒Si bond, placed before optimization at 1.0 Å from the O atom. Due to the cluster size, a two-layer ONIOM [47–51] approximation was adopted, where the outer part of the system was treated by the LANL2DZ basis set and the inner part, represented by the Si8Al2O31H22Cu2 cluster (both T3 sites plus all their first-neighbour T-sites) shown in Fig. 2 was treated by a more extended basis set. In this framework, a combination of the Ahlrichs' “def2” basis sets [52,53] was adopted for the inner part of the ONIOM cluster, as follows: def2-TZV for saturating H atoms, def2-TZVP for N, O, Al, Si and def2-QZVP for Cu. Since previous work [54] showed that this choice of basis functions has the effect to minimize the Basis Set Superposition Error (BSSE) both in the coordination of Cu+ to the zeolite framework and in the interaction of NO with coordinated Cu+ (less than 1.0 kcal mol−1) no counterpoise corrections are provided in the present work. As in previous computational studies [19-27,32-37,54], the hybrid B3LYP functional [55,56] was employed for all calculations also in the present work. The two-step procedure employed for geometry optimization, consisting in a pre-optimization of bond distances with fixed angles and dihedrals, and a further optimization of all geometrical parameters with frozen OH terminal groups, was described in more detail elsewhere [33-35,54,57]. Such an approach has the effect to impose the specific constraints of the zeolite structure to the cluster model and, at the same time, to avoid the occurrence of imaginary frequencies (apart from the true transition states) in the vibrational analysis. This allows the calculation of thermal and entropic contributions at variable temperature to be performed without artefacts. The (2S+1) spin multiplicity assigned to each optimized structure is shown throughout the figures of the forthcoming sections. All calculations were performed by the Gaussian-09 code [58]. Atomic charges and spin densities were computed by the Mulliken Population analysis [59], which for this kind of systems was found [35] to produce qualitatively equivalent results as the Natural Population analysis (NPA) [60]. The molecular visualization Molden [61] program was employed for both input preparation and output inspection. Figures were obtained by the Mercury [62] and GIMP [63] programs. Tables reporting the energetics of all stationary points along the reaction paths investigated in the present work are available as supplementary material (Table S1). Results and discussion Active site structure As shown in Fig. 2, the 10-membered ring considered in the present work lays at the intersection between the linear and the sinusoidal channels of ZSM-5 which run along the b and the a crystallographic axes, respectively. Each ring consists of two specular halves through the mirror plane identified by O23, O24, O25 and O26 [46]. Al atoms are located at the T3 crystallographic positions, which are separated by two specular T12 sites. Each Cu+ ion is coordinated by two O atoms of the corresponding AlO4 unit, with Cu‒O distances of about 2.04 Å (Fig. 3 ) and the Cu‒Cu distance of 4.57 Å in the reduced catalyst. This particular site was chosen for calculations because (i) it appears to be visually similar to that described in [38], (ii) the Cu‒Cu distance is also similar and (iii) the reciprocal orientation of the Cu+ ions is compatible with all intermediates and transition states involved in the reaction mechanism. Moreover, as outlined in [19], the T3 tetrahedral site, located at the intersection between the linear and the sinusoidal channels, appears to be particularly suited to play a catalytic role because it is easily accessible to substrate molecules, and also because both Cu(I) ions are coordinated by only two oxygens of the zeolite framework. Two-fold coordination is an essential feature for reactivity at difference, for instance, from sites where tetracoordinated Cu(I) is very stable but less reactive [35]. A crystallographic study on Tl-ZSM-5 [64] suggested that the Si/Al replacement is most likely to occur at the T10 site but, as reported in [19], a Cu(I) ion at this site is preferentially four-fold coordinated and this wouldn't be so favourable to catalytic activity [35]. In the same study [64], it was also shown that the T3 or T6 sites may be the second more favourable sites for the Si/Al replacement, after T10. A graphical inspection of the ZSM-5 structure [46] showed that pairs of T3 or T6 sites occur in different 10-membered rings, but with very similar geometrical features (distance and reciprocal orientation) so that they are expected to display a similar reactivity. Spectroscopic studies [65,66] showed that chemiluminescence spectra of Cu-ZSM-5 are characterised by two different bands at 480 and 540 nm, the former being associated to a Cu2+ ion in proximity of two Al sites, the latter to a (Cu2+–OH)+ ion coordinated to a single Al site. The band at 540 nm was found to be correlated to the catalytic activity of NO decomposition. Further DFT studies [20,68] showed that the band at 480 nm is very likely related to tetracoordinated Cu2+ within the M6 and Z6 rings along the channels walls of ZSM-5, whereas that at 540 nm to dicoordinated Cu+, possibly at the T6 and T12 sites at the intersection between the linear and the sinusoidal channels, as previously investigated in [19]. However, if T6 and T12 sites are involved, it should be the same also for the T3 and T9 sites, because the T3-T12-T12-T3 and T6-T9-T9-T6 sequences appear to be specular to each other within the ZSM-5 structure [46]. It should be recalled that, due to the Lowenstein's rule, the T9 and T12 sites in the above sequences are unsuitable to host a pair of Al atoms and, as a consequence, a Cu-pair could only be coordinated by the T6 sites of T6-T9-T9-T6 or, as in the present study, by the T3 sites of T3-T12-T12-T3 (see Fig. 2). According to [19] also the T1, T2 and T7 sites are capable to host dicoordinated Cu+, and therefore to be potentially involved in the chemiluminescence band at 540 nm. However, a pair of T2 sites appear at opposite sides of the ten-membered ring represented in the present study (Fig. 2) but, since these sites are separated by four T-sites (T2-T3-T12-T12-T3-T2 sequence, see Fig. 2) their reciprocal distance is larger (8.8 Å) than the distance between the T3 (7.5 Å) and T6 pairs (7.6 Å) and therefore they appear less suited to be active according to the investigated mechanisms. Finally, T1 and T7 are sites where Cu+ may be dicoordinated but it was reported that in these sites a coordination to three framework oxygens may also occur [19,67]. In addition, calculations showed [33,68] that even in case Cu+ is two-fold coordinated to T1 or T7, it points more to the inner part of the M7 ring (i.e. to the channel wall) than to the inner part of the just nearby ten-membered ring. Taking into account all the above considerations, pairs of T3 or T6 sites located along the T3-T12-T12-T3 or the T6-T9-T9-T6 sequences appear to be the best suited (and nearly equivalent) to catalyse NO or N2O decomposition through the mechanism suggested in the present study. N2O formation On the basis of former studies [29,30,33-35], the first step of the NO decomposition process is the formation of N2O from two NO molecules. These are N-down adsorbed on both Cu+ ions of the active site, as shown in the 01 and 02 structures of Fig. 3. Although the N-down interaction is the most favourable, NO may also O-down interact with the active site (structure 03) and the adsorption of a second NO molecule gives rise to the 04 structure, which consists in a cis-hyponitrite anion coordinated to the active site. As shown by the Mulliken analysis, the latter structure is originated by a net charge transfer from copper ions to the adsorbed NO molecules, which bind to each other (the N‒N distance in 04 is 1.25 Å) and give rise to the anion. As outlined in former studies [33–35], in the framework of Mulliken analysis Cu+ (d 10 valence shell electronic configuration) is a closed-shell ion that displays a spin density equal to zero. An increase of the spin density (reported in all figures containing molecular structures) to positive values reveals at least a partial oxidation to Cu2+ (d9 valence shell electronic configuration). At the same time, Mulliken atomic charges (also reported in the figures containing molecular structures) are fractional numbers, always lower than formal oxidation numbers, which are not to be considered in absolute terms but in terms of their variation from a structure to another one. As an example, the increase of both positive charge and spin density on copper ions on going from the reduced catalyst (ZCu2 ) to structure 04 is consistent with a partial copper oxidation, although the calculated charge fraction on both ions is lower than the formal 2+ oxidation state. At the same time, the formation of the hyponitrite anion in 04 is put in evidence not only by the N‒N bond distance of 1.25 Å, but also by the net negative charge and by the decrease of spin density in the N2O4 fragment with respect to two isolated NO molecules. Mulliken atomic charges and spin densities are provided in all figures reporting molecular structures throughout the present article, in order to allow this kind of interpretation of computational results even if, for the sake of brevity, the related descriptions will be omitted throughout the text. In the present study, the cis-hyponitrite anion decomposes through the 05(TS) transition state, giving rise to the oxidized catalyst (ZCu2O) and to N2O, which remains coordinated to one of the copper ions of the catalyst, as in the 06 structure. This reaction, independently of the temperature, has an activation energy of about 10 kcal mol−1, so that N2O may be produced even at room temperature on the present model site. Experimentally, N2O was already observed as an intermediate of NO decomposition and its formation was detected near room temperature [17,18]. Recent experimental studies showed that N2O formation from two NO molecules occurs through a cis-Cu(N2O2) complex also in biological systems [69]. All possible NO decomposition processes catalysed by copper zeolites require the formation of the N2O intermediate from two NO molecules [29,30,33-35]. Different mechanisms can be further characterized, depending on how N2O is decomposed to give the final products. In general, N2O decomposition can either take place through a spin-allowed or a spin-forbidden mechanism, as shown in the forthcoming sections. N2O decomposition Spin-allowed mechanisms The 06 adduct can react immediately through the 07(TS) transition state to give the 08 structure, where O2 strongly coordinates both copper ions of the active site and N2 is weakly coordinated to only one copper ion. Independently of the temperature, the latter step has an activation energy of about 41–44 kcal mol−1, which is expected to be rate-determining for the present mechanism. The stepwise desorption of N2 and O2 (the latter from the 09 structure) yields the reaction products, O2 + N2, and the catalyst in its reduced form, ZCu2 . Notably, the 09 structure, where O2 coordinates both Cu ions of the active site, may be related to the bis(μ-oxo)dicopper ion, [Cu2(μ-O2)]2+, or to the (μ-η2:η2-peroxo)dicopper ion, [Cu2(μ-η2:η2-O2)]2+, already proposed [70,71] as possible intermediates of N2O decomposition catalysed by Cu-ZSM-5. The just described mechanism is the simplest that could be characterized. A possible alternative is shown in Fig. 4 . N2O can be partially desorbed from the 06 structure but, due to the zeolite cavities, it remains in the proximity of the active site giving other weakly interacting structures, such as the 10 complex. In this framework, N2O can also re-adsorb coordinating its nitrogen atom, as in the 11 adduct. The decomposition of 11 through the 12(TS) transition state gives again the 08 structure, then 09 after N2 desorption, and finally the reduced catalyst ZCu2 with free N2 + O2. In this case, the N2O decomposition has an activation energy of 55–60 kcal mol−1, probably related to the geometrical strain in the five-membered ring of the 12(TS) transition state. From the adsorption of two NO molecules to the products formation, all substrate-catalyst structures described so far are stable in the triplet spin state (2S+1 = 3) and this implies that both mechanisms are spin-allowed. Spin-forbidden mechanism A third possibility is represented by the O-down adsorption of N2O on a second active site in its reduced form, which gives the adduct named 13 in Fig. 5 . The latter structure corresponds to that indicated as μ-1,1-O in [38] and can be decomposed through the 14(TS) transition state to give N2 and a second oxidized active site, ZCu2O. The latter step, which is the one considered in [38], is spin-forbidden because 13 and 14(TS) are closed-shell structures (2S+1 = 1) but, among the products, ZCu2O is stable in the triplet state. As shown in Fig. 6 , the activation energy of the latter reaction was calculated by plotting the electronic energy of both the singlet and the triplet state of the system as a function of the r(O‒N) distance of N2O, the elongation of which represents the evolution from reactants to products. At About 1.20 Å the most stable form is the 13 adduct in its singlet state, whereas the corresponding triplet state is nearly 45 kcal mol−1 higher in energy. As the r(O‒N) distance increases, the singlet curve reaches a maximum which coincides with the 14(TS) transition state. At larger distances the triplet state becomes the most stable and evolves into the ZCu2O+N2 products. The products position along the r(O‒N) scale was obtained by extrapolating the triplet state curve at the corresponding energy value. The crossing point between the singlet and the triplet state occurs in the descending part of both curves, at r(O‒N) ≃ 1.70 Å. It was checked that both singlet and triplet structures optimized in the r(O‒N) ≃ 1.60–1.70 Å range have similar r(Cu‒O) and r(N‒N) distances, indicating that this is the true crossing region between the two surfaces. Since the crossing point occurs in the descending part of the curve, the activation energy of the reaction has to be calculated as the energy difference between 14(TS) and 13. The so-obtained value ranges between 13.6 and 14.6 kcal mol−1, depending on temperature (Fig. 5). These values are slightly lower with respect to those calculated in previous work (15–19 kcal mol−1) when the reaction occurs on pairs of Cu+ ions in different sites of ZSM-5 [33–35]. However, the same activation energy calculated on a single Cu+ ion is considerably larger (40–45 kcal mol−1) [32], indicating that the formation of the stable [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ structure plays a key catalytic role, as suggested in [38].The value of 13.6 kcal mol−1, obtained with inclusion of ZPE and Gibbs free energy corrections at 298.15 K, suggests that the reaction can take place at room temperature, as reported in [38] where the corresponding activation energy is 11 kcal mol−1. An apparent activation energy of 2.0 kcal mol−1 was also calculated in [38] as the energy difference between the transition state along the singlet state curve and the reactants, i.e. ZCu2 + N2O. This value was found in agreement with the experimental value of 2.5 kcal mol−1 obtained in the same study from an Arrhenius plot. Although the corresponding value of 1.3 kcal mol−1 (with ZPE and Gibbs free energy corrections) computed in the present study is also in substantial agreement with [38], we think that the activation energy of the ZCu2 + N2O → ZCu2O + N2 reaction should be calculated from the ZCu2‒ON2 adduct (the 13 structure in the present work) and not from the reactants as such. The discrepancy existing between the experimental value of 2.5 kcal mol−1 and those of 11–13 kcal mol−1 obtained from DFT calculations can not be explained at present, but it may possibly be ascribed to some difficulty in reproducing very low activation energies by theoretical calculations [72,73]. After the latter step, the products obtained are N2 and two active sites in their oxidized form, ZCu2O. In order for the system to react again, these sites need to be brought back to their reduced form ZCu2 . Taking into account that N2O was already decomposed into N2 in the former step and that the further production of N2O from NO implies the formation of new oxidized sites, the only possibility to have a net ZCu2O reduction is represented by its reaction with a third NO molecule, ZCu2O + NO → ZCu2 + NO2. As a matter of fact, this mechanism requires that NO binds to the oxygen atom of the [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ structure, giving a NO2 molecule coordinated to the active site (structure 15). The latter reaction is also spin-forbidden because the reactants, ZCu2O + NO, have a total of three unpaired electrons and are stable in the quartet spin state but the products, ZCu2 + NO2, have only one unpaired electron (NO2) and are stable in the doublet state. In spite of this, on similar systems the above reaction was already shown to proceed without activation energy [31,34,35] and it is reasonable that the same occurs also on the present site. As shown in Fig. 5, the 15 complex, where NO2 has one of its oxygen atoms in bridging position between the copper ions of the active site, represents a stable intermediate along the reaction path. However, if NO2 is desorbed and interacts with a new ZCu2O site, the 16 adduct can be formed. Further reaction through the 17(TS) transition state leads to the formation of NO and O2, both coordinated to the active site (structure 18). NO is immediately desorbed whereas O2, before its final desorption, remains coordinated to the active site giving an adduct equivalent to structure 09, already identified within the spin-allowed reaction path. In the present reaction path, although the spin-forbidden N2O decomposition has an activation energy of about 15 kcal mol−1, the reaction that leads to O2 formation and catalyst reduction through the 16 → 17(TS) → 18 step has a calculated activation energy of 48–50 kcal mol−1, and therefore is probably slow even at 773.15 K. Additional structures and vibrational analysis In this section some additional structures are reported in order to establish if they could also be involved in the just outlined reaction mechanisms. At the same time, the most typical vibrational frequencies calculated for the main intermediates described in this and in the previous sections are compared with literature data [74–76] with the aim to validate the mechanisms proposed in the present study. The additional structures shown in this section are in part based on the same active site described in Figs. 2-5, characterised by a pair of Cu(I) ions, and in part on an active site where the Si/Al substitution occurs at a single T3 position, with only one charge-balancing Cu(I) ion. The latter structures were optimised only in order to allow a better comparison between computational results and experimental FTIR data. In this case, the Si47AlO116H40Cu cluster (instead of Si46Al2O116H40Cu2) was optimised according to the procedure described in Section 2. All additional structures are shown in Fig. 7 for the active site based on Cu-pairs (structures 19–30) and in Fig. 8 for that based on a single-Cu site (structures 31–44). The only exception in Fig. 7 is represented by structure 30, where a Si38Al2CuO98H36 cluster taken from previous studies [34,35] and representing the M6 ring was optimised with the aim to model the vibrational frequency of NO interacting with the Cu2+ ion in Cu-ZSM-5, also reported in [74,75]. The computed vibrational frequencies reported in Table S2 (supplementary material) correspond to the structures shown in Figs. 2, 3, 5 and 7, those reported in Table S3 to the structures shown in Fig. 8. The main problem related to the frequencies obtained by quantum mechanical calculations is that they are generally overestimated with respect to experiments. As a consequence, scaling factors are employed to compare computed and experimental values. For the frequencies calculated by the B3LYP functional, a scale factor of about 0.97 was often proposed [77–79]. However, more recent studies [80,81] showed that not only one, but several scale factors may be used, depending on the particular molecules or functional groups under investigation. For the present study, we obtained suitable scale factors by comparing the vibrational frequencies calculated at the B3LYP/def2-TZVP level for some simple representative molecules such as NO, NO+, NO−, N2, O2, N2O, NO2, N2O3, N2O5 with the corresponding experimental values [82]. According to the values reported in Table S4 the scale factors of 0.954 or 0.950 were established, depending on whether N2O5 was included in the reference data set or not. The vibrational frequencies reported in Tables S2 and S3 were compared with experimental values available in the literature, in particular from Ref. [75]. Tables inspection shows that, after scaling, there is a general agreement between calculated and experimental frequencies or that, at least, the majority of the calculated frequencies find a correspondence in the experimental spectra and vice-versa. However, due to the complexity of the spectra and to the large number of possible structures, it is not easy to afford a completely clear and unambiguous distinction on the basis of this kind of comparison. As an example, several structures (06, 10, 11, 13, 22, 40, 41) involve the coordination of N2O to the catalyst active site, either based on a Cu-pair or on a single-Cu ion. Structures 13 and 40, where N2O is O-down adsorbed on reduced Cu+ sites (on a Cu-pair and on a single-Cu site, respectively) display N=N stretching frequencies that can both be related to the peak at 2236 cm−1 in the experimental spectra [74,75]. Structures 06, 10, 11, where N2O is either O-down (06) or N-down (10, 11) adsorbed on oxidised active sites based on Cu-pairs can also be related to the peak at 2236 cm−1. Structures 22 and 41, where N2O is N-down adsorbed on a reduced Cu-pair and on a reduced single-Cu site, respectively, show some more variability in the N=N stretching, so that 22 shows an adsorption shifted to a lower frequency (2161 cm−1) and 41 to a higher one (2287 cm−1) with respect to the former structures. Both frequencies, however, find some correspondence in the experimental spectra, although to adsorptions that are generally assigned to interacting N2 (2156 and 2295 cm−1) [75,76]. Interestingly, there is not a full agreement between the experimental frequencies of N2 adsorbed on Cu+, which occur at 2156 and 2134 cm−1 according to [75] and at 2295 cm−1 according to [76]. Among the structures optimised in the present work, those where N2 coordinates Cu+ through a single N atom (25 and 34) display a NN stretching closer to 2295 cm−1, those where N2 coordinates both N atoms to a pair of Cu+ ions (26) or to a single Cu+ ion (35) show a better agreement to the bands at 2156–2134 cm−1. Since 35 is about 10 kcal mol−1 less stable than 34 at any temperature, the band at 2156 cm−1 may be possibly related to N2 adsorbed between pairs of Cu+ ions (26) giving an evidence for the occurrence of Cu-pairs. However, due to the complexity of the spectra, to the large number of possible structures and, presumably, to the lower occurrence of Cu+ pairs with respect to single Cu+ sites, we think that the above hypothesis should be taken with great caution. The structures where N2 coordinates an oxidized active site (08, 27, 44) show a very weak interaction, with a Cu⋯N2 distance of about 2.7 Å in 08 and 27, or even larger (3.16 Å) in 44. In these cases, the scaled stretching frequency of the NN bond of 2340 cm−1 nearly coincides with the experimental gas-phase value of 2330 cm−1 [82]. The structures where NO coordinates a single Cu+ site (2, 21, 31) display a scaled N=O stretching frequency at about 1810–1818 cm−1, very close to the experimental value of 1810 cm−1. In 21, which was derived by addition of a second NO molecule to 03, one of the NO molecules is η2-coordinated to one Cu+ ion and displays a N=O stretching frequency (1507 cm−1) that coincides with a peak at 1500 cm−1, ascribed to unidentate nitrate groups [75]. Cu+ dinitrosyls (structures 32, 33) even after scaling show N=O stretching frequencies (1854 and 1788 cm−1) slightly overestimated with respect to experimental values (1824 and 1733 cm−1) [74,75]. When NO coordinates N-down an oxidised active site (structures 28, 43) the scaled N=O stretching occurs at about 1900 cm−1, in good agreement with experimental spectra [74,75]. In structure 18 the O-down interaction of the NO molecule with a partially oxidised active site is so weak that the N=O stretching frequency coincides with that of gas-phase NO (1876 cm−1) [82]. Structures 1, 3 and 19, where a single NO molecule is adsorbed by the Cu-pair active site, display scaled N=O stretching frequencies of 1604, 1394 and 1659 cm−1, respectively. Among these, the frequencies at 1600–1650 cm−1 are within a range that also contains some typical frequencies of NO2 and N2O3 [74,75], which are presumably superimposed in the experimental spectra. The stretching at 1394 cm−1 is not clearly distinguishable in the experimental spectra, since a broad and undefined adsorption is present in that region. Structure 19, in particular, upon addition of a second NO molecule may give a structure (not shown) very similar to 02, with nearly the same vibrational pattern, or structure 20 with the formation of an hyponitrite ion that coordinates both Cu+ ions of the active site. Although structure 19 appears to be more stable than 03, structure 20 is about 15 kcal mol−1 less stable than 04, so that we have chosen the latter to simulate the decomposition of the hyponitrite anion which leads to N2O release. The N=N stretching in 20 is at about 1270 cm−1, slightly lower with respect to the lowest frequencies recorded in [74,75]. In any case the formation of N2O, which takes place at relatively low temperature [17,18], is not energetically demanding and may also occur across parallel and nearly equivalent pathways, without particular effects on the whole NO decomposition rate. Interestingly, the unscaled N=N stretching frequency of 1376 cm−1 calculated for 04 is comparable to the corresponding experimental value of 1390 cm−1 measured in sodium hyponitrite [83]. However, the scaled frequency of the same vibrational mode is 1307 cm−1, which corresponds to a peak at about 1300 cm−1, detectable in nearly all spectra of Cu-ZSM-5 in the presence of nitrogen oxides [74,75]. Structure 30, which represents the adsorption of NO on a Cu2+ site, turned out to be more stable in the triplet than in the singlet state (not shown) and displays the scaled stretching of the N=O bond at about 1900 cm−1, in good agreement with experimental spectra [74,75]. The structures where NO2 is present are 15, 16, 23 for the active site based on a Cu-pair, 36 and 37 for the single-Cu active site. These structures display variable NO stretching frequencies, depending on the different coordination patterns. The stretching frequencies of 15 (1615 cm−1), 16 (1295 cm−1), 36 (1280 cm−1) and 37 (1575 cm−1) find a correspondence in the experimental spectra [74,75], that of 23 (1255 cm−1) appears to be lower with respect to experimental values. In addition, structure 23 was calculated to be 6–7 kcal mol−1 less stable than 15 and for this reason was not included in the pathway employed for turnover frequency (TOF) calculations in the next section. The structures where N2O3 is present are 29 (Cu-pair site) and 39 (single-Cu site). In both cases the scaled vibrational frequencies find some correspondence in the experimental spectra, although the lowest ones (1226–1238 cm−1) appear to be somehow underestimated. The structures where the nitrate radical coordinates the active site are 24 (Cu-pair site) and 38 (single-Cu site). In both cases, the scaled stretching of the non-coordinated NO bond is at 1570–1580 cm−1, in good agreement with the experimental peak at about 1572 cm−1 [74,75]. The coordination to Cu+ ions shifts the stretching of the other NO bonds of the nitrate radical towards frequencies lower than 1200 cm−1, outside the range investigated in [74,75]. As shown in Figs. 7 and 8, the nitrate radical is particularly stable when coordinated both to Cu-pairs and to single Cu+ ions. Although for the sake of brevity the corresponding calculations are not shown, we have also checked that it can be formed without activation energy by addition of a NO2 molecule to the oxidised catalyst (e.g. ZCu2O+NO2 → 24, and 42+NO2 → 38). It is also worth mentioning that structure 24 is about 17 kcal mol−1 more stable than structure 16, so that its formation could represent a termination step along the spin-forbidden pathway shown in Fig. 5. In spite of this, 24+ZCu2+N2 (Fig. 7) has a higher energy than 15+ZCu2O+N2 which is the point of lowest energy along the reaction path shown in Fig. 5 and therefore represents the TOF-determining intermediate (TDI) as shown in the next section. Kinetic analysis As suggested in Figs. 3, 4, and 5, three different mechanisms are possible for NO decomposition on the investigated catalytic site. The related energetic diagrams are reported in Fig. 9 , where the diagrams corresponding to the spin-allowed mechanisms are shown in (a), and those corresponding to the spin-forbidden one in (b). For each mechanism three diagrams are reported, at 0, 273.15 and 773.15 K, respectively. The relative energies are those corresponding to the individual structures shown in Figs. 3, 4, and 5. All energies are corrected for the ZPE and those at 273.15 and 773.15 K also include Gibbs free energy corrections. As already observed in previous work [34,35], all intermediates and transition states tend to be destabilized with respect to reactants as the temperature increases. The data shown in Fig. 9 were employed to perform a kinetic analysis based on the Energetic Span Model developed by Kozuch and Shaik [42–45]. This model allows the calculation of the turnover frequency (TOF) of the whole process, expressed as substrate molecules converted per active site per second. The results were obtained from the following equation TOF = k B T h e Δ G r / RT − 1 ∑ i , j = 1 e ( T i − I j − δ G ij ) / RT where T i and I j represent the i-th transition state and the j-th intermediate along the reaction path, and ẟG ij is equal to ∆G r (Gibbs free energy difference between reactants and products) if i > j or to 0 if i ≤ j. The above TOF equation was originally developed by assuming that every minimum is followed by a transition state and vice-versa. When simulations involve gas-solid heterogeneous catalysis, instead, adsorption-desorption steps may occur without a specific transition state. To overcome this problem, as recommended in [45], when two consecutive minima are related by an adsorption-desorption step, the equation was applied by introducing a fictitious T i transition state between them, at the same energy as the higher of the two minima. The values obtained in this way are reported in Table 1 . The calculated TOF values show that the first spin-allowed mechanism (Fig. 3) is the fastest. The TOF of 9.6 s −1 calculated at 773.15 K is consistent with available experimental results [12,84]. The second spin-allowed (Fig. 4) and the spin-forbidden (Fig. 5) reaction mechanisms are slower (TOFs of 2.4 × 10−5 and 9.6 × 10−9 s −1, respectively) because of a high energy difference (Energetic Span) between the most stable intermediate (TOF-Determining Intermediate, TDI) and the highest transition state (TOF-Determining Transition State, TDTS). As shown in Table 1, for the first spin-allowed mechanism, both the 01+NO and 06 intermediates, which are nearly isoenergetic at 773.15 K, can be considered as the TDI, whereas the 07(TS) transition state is the TDTS. The corresponding Energetic Span was calculated assuming 06 as the TDI at 0.0 and 298.15 K and 01+NO at 773.15 K. It shows little variations with temperature and increases from 41.5 kcal mol−1 at 0.0 K to 45.0 kcal mol−1 at 773.15 K. For the second spin-allowed mechanism, the 06, 10 and 11 structures have nearly the same energy at all temperatures and, with the addition of 01+NO at 773.15 K, can be considered as the TDI. Independently of the temperature, the TDTS is always the 12(TS) structure. Also for this mechanism the Energetic Span slightly increases with temperature (from 55.7 to 61.3 kcal mol−1) with a TOF of about 2.4 × 10−5 s−1 at 773.15 K. The lower TOF with respect to the first mechanism arises from the higher energy of the 12(TS) transition state in comparison to 07(TS). For the mechanism based on the spin-forbidden decomposition of N2O, the TDI is the 15 complex, where just formed NO2 coordinates the ZCu2 active site. Because of such a favourable interaction, the 15 complex remains the lowest point of the reaction path, and therefore the TDI, independently of the temperature. At 773.15 K, also the sum of the 2ZCu2O+N2+NO intermediates has a comparable energy. The 17(TS) transition state is also the TDTS in the whole range of temperatures. For this mechanism, the Energetic Span is about 74 kcal mol−1 independently of the temperature, with a low TOF of 9.6 × 10−9 s −1 a 773.15 K. Interestingly, the bridged N-down mono-nitrosyl complex 01 is stable in the whole range of temperatures and becomes one of the TDIs at 773.15 K for the spin-allowed mechanisms. The N-down di-nitrosyl 02, instead, appears to be stable at 0.0 K, but at increasing temperature is more destabilized than other structures along the reaction path, so that it is never effective in determining the energetic span of the process. Discussion and conclusions The target of the present study was a DFT investigation on the NO decomposition mechanism catalysed by a pair of Cu+ ions located in a 10-membered ring of ZSM-5. Al/Si substitution occurs at two T3 sites specular to each other and separated by two tetrahedral Si-sites. Each Cu+ ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of the corresponding AlO4 − site. Catalytic sites with similar features were already considered by other authors [38] as possible active sites for N2O decomposition, without providing the crystallographic numbering of the T-sites involved and/or any practical indication about their exact position within the ZSM-5 structure. The present work represents an attempt to locate an active site with the features described in [38], as well as to define the whole mechanism of NO decomposition. The main conclusions may be summarized as follows: 1) In the considered site, the Cu+ pair displays the right geometrical features to allow the catalytic activity, namely both ions are dicoordinated by framework oxygens and the Cu‒Cu distance does not exceed 4.57 Å. Larger distances were already shown to cause higher activation energies in the decomposition of both N2O [38] and NO [85]. 2) For NO decomposition, three possible mechanisms were defined. All of them require the concerted action of both Cu+ ions and the initial formation of the N2O intermediate, which is decomposed in the further steps. N2O decomposition may occur via two different spin-allowed reactions with the oxidized active site, or via a spin-forbidden reaction with the reduced active site. 3) Among the spin-allowed mechanisms, one turns out to be faster (TOF=9.6 s−1) than the other one (TOF=2.4×10−5 s−1) by virtue of a lower activation energy of the N2O decomposition step (the energetic span is 45.0 vs. 61.3 kcal mol−1 at 773.15 K) probably associated to a different degree of geometrical strain in the structure of the TDTS. The site investigated in the present work may be active for NO decomposition if the first mechanism is considered. 4) In the spin-forbidden mechanism, as suggested in [38], it was confirmed that the N2O intermediate can bind a reduced active site with its oxygen atom in bridging position between the Cu+ ions. The decomposition of this complex generates N2 and the stable [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ species, the occurrence of which was hypothesized on the basis of both theoretical calculations and spectroscopic measurements [38]. The low activation energy allows the latter reaction to occur even at room temperature. 5) In spite of the activation energy required for the reaction with N2O, the [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ species quickly reacts with a further NO molecule, giving rise to NO2. As documented in previous work [31,34,35], such a reaction takes place in the doublet state without activation energy. In the present site, the further NO2 desorption is strongly endothermic (41.8 kcal mol−1) at 0.0 K but becomes feasible at higher temperature (9.1 kcal mol−1 at 773.15 K). This is in agreement with Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) experiments on Cu-ZSM-5 [86] which showed a sharp desorption peak at 650 K, compatible with a strong NO2 interaction on dimeric Cu+ sites. NO2 was also formed during TPD experiments of NO on similar samples [86], where NO2 desorption starts with a broad peak at 425 K and is completed by a sharp peak at 650 K. This suggests that NO2 is produced even at low temperature from NO and some extra-framework oxygen atoms, possibly located on both monomeric and dimeric Cu+ sites. In this context, NO2 desorption at 425 K may occur from monomeric sites and that at 650 K from dimeric sites. A sharp NO2 desorption peak at 650 K was also reported for samples at relatively high aluminium content (Si/Al = 14.7 and 13.3) [17,18] were the occurrence of Cu+ pairs is possible. 6) NO2, once desorbed, reacts with a second [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ site, to form O2 + NO. In this way, NO behaves not only as the reaction substrate, but also as an oxygen carrier from one site to another. However, the large energy difference (energetic span) between the most stable minimum and the highest transition state along the reaction path results in a rather low TOF (10−9 s−1). Therefore, this mechanism appears unlikely for the whole NO decomposition, in spite of the low activation energy of the spin-forbidden N2O decomposition step. This is in agreement with previous experimental studies [15,16] where it was shown that a small amount of NO promotes the decomposition of N2O catalysed by isolated Cu+ ions, but has the opposite effect when the same process occurs on pairs of Cu+ ions. 7) As far as the decomposition of pure N2O is concerned, on the basis of the present computations an oscillating behaviour may be possible on the investigated site, arising from the fast spin-forbidden N2O decomposition (ZCu2+N2O → ZCu2O+N2) followed by a relatively slower reduction of the active site according to the (ZCu2O+N2O → ZCu2+N2+O2) spin-allowed reaction. However an oscillating behaviour, typical of zeolites with high Si/Al [87] but generally not observed when the Si/Al ratio is ≤ 18 [88], was not mentioned in [38], where N2O decomposition was possibly monitored within a time interval not so extended to appreciate any fluctuations of the N2O decomposition rate. 8) Provided suitable scaling factors are employed, calculations showed a general agreement between DFT frequencies and experimental FTIR data. However, the complexity of the experimental spectra and the large amount of possible intermediates do not always allow a simple interpretation of spectroscopic data, in particular when species as NO2, N2O3 or nitrates are involved. For a direct and unambiguous identification of intermediate species and reaction products the use of gas chromatography and mass spectrometry [17,18] is therefore recommended. As far as N2O3 is concerned, it was suggested [75] that it could play a role in the NO decomposition, but such an hypothesis was contradicted [89] because of the high activation energy calculated for N2O3 decomposition. In the present study, a comparison between computational results and FTIR spectra showed the possible occurrence of nitrate radicals, which are expected to form stable complexes with active sites based on both single-Cu(I) ions and Cu(I)-pairs. The role of nitrate radicals in the NO decomposition mechanism is worth of further investigations. coredata.dc:description: The decomposition of NO catalysed by Cu+ pairs coordinated at the Al-substituted T3 sites of the 10-membered rings of Cu-ZSM-5 was studied by means of DFT/ONIOM calculations. Three mechanisms for NO decomposition were defined on the active site, all based on the formation and further decomposition of an hyponitrite anion, which gives the N2O molecule and a [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ bridge, where both copper ions are oxidized. N2O can react with the oxidized active site according to two different spin-allowed mechanisms which give immediately the products, N2 + O2. Otherwise, N2O reacts with a new reduced site according to a spin-forbidden mechanism which gives N2 and a second [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ bridge. When the latter mechanism occurs, reduced sites are restored by further reaction of [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ with NO and desorption of NO2, which is finally decomposed on a second [Cu‒O‒Cu]2+ site, giving O2 + NO. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) calculated by means of the Energetic Span model showed that one of the spin-allowed mechanisms should be relatively fast, whereas the spin-forbidden one is expected to be extremely slow. Computational results were discussed with reference to experimental data available in the literature.
coredata.dc:title: A DFT study on Cu-ZSM-5 as a catalyst for NO decomposition: Possible activity of a Cu(I) pair located at the T3 tetrahedral sites
